column4: Steve  Subject: Gifts from Austrian Bakery   Dear Comptroller Ahmad and Steve:     Today we received a ginger bread house and a platter of cookies from the Austrian  Bakery. We accept the gift  on behalf of the City of Chicago and will make both available  to guests of the 43rd ward office.    Thanks

column11: IL 60633   FINAL ORDER   YOU  ARE  HEREBY  NOTIFIED  that.  on  April  15
column13: the  Chicago  Commission  on  Human  Relations  issued a ruling  in favor of Respondent in  the above-captioned matter.  The findings  of fact  and specific terms of the ruling are enclosed.  Based on the ruling
column14: this case is  hereby DISMISSED.   Pursuant to Commission Regulations l 00( 15) and 250.150
column15: Complainant may seek review of this Order  by filing a petition for a common law writ of' certiorari with the Chancery Division of the Circuit Court  of Cook County according to applicable law.   CHICAGO COMMISSION ON HUMAN RELATIONS  Dana V.  Starks
column16: Chair and Commissioner   City of Chicago    COMMISSION ON HUMAN RELATIONS    740 N. Sedgwick
column21: 312/744-1088 (TDD)    IN THE MATTER OF:   Ellyn VanDyck  Complainant
column22: v.   Old Time Tap  Respondent.   Case No.:  04-E-1 03   Date of Ruling: April  15
column23: 2009   I.   INTRODUCTION   FINAL RULING   Complainant Ellyn VanDyck filed a Complaint on June 10
column25: alleging that she suffered  discrimination in violation of the Chicago Human Rights Ordinance based on perceived disability  when she was fired from her job as a fill-in bartender at Respondent
column27: located at 13501  S.  Brandon A venue in Chicago.  Old Time Tap maintains that after Ms. VanDyck missed work due  to a medical condition unrelated to her job
column28: she failed to retum to work; then the bartender for whom  she was filling in returned to work
column29: so Ms.  VanDyck was no longer needed.  Old Time Tap denies  that it had knowledge of her medical condition or that her medical condition had anything to do with  its decision to replace her.   The  Commission  on  Human  Relations  found  substantial  evidence  of a  violation  of the  Chicago Human Rights Ordinance and advanced the case to the administrative hearing process.  Ms.  Van  Dyck  represented  herself  pro  se  at  the  administrative  hearing
column30: and  Old  Time  Tap  was  represented  by counsel.  The  hearing  was  conducted on  September  10
column32: and  post -hearing  briefing was completed on December 22
column33: 2008.   II.   FACTUAL FINDINGS   A.   1.   The Facts   Complainant
column35: was hired by Old Time Tap  as  a  fill-in  bartender   sometime in  2003.  (Tr.  13.)   2.   3.   Old Time Tap is  owned and operated by Don and Christine Jones.  (Tr. 93
column36: 127 .)   The job opening that Van Dyck filled  arose when bartender Geri Polozet chose to   reduce her shifts to one day a week because of her pregnancy.  (Tr. 94-96.)   4.   VanDyck's  original  shifts  were  Wednesday  and  Sunday  nights
column38: she was  cut back to just Sundays.  (Tr.  12.)  Respondent's Exhibit (""RX"")  I
column39: which was  received into evidence. reflects some if not all of the hours VanDyck worked at Old Time Tap.   5.   The last day VanDyck worked at Old Time Tap was Sunday
column43: for  reasons  that had  nothing to  do  with  her  work
column47: and had to go to the hospital.  (Tr.  16
column48: 17.)   6.   The  parties  agree  that  Old  Time  Tap  bears  no  responsibility  for  her  injury  or   hospitalization.  (Tr. 75.)   7.   She remained in the hospital for four days and remembers little about that experience.  (Tr.  17.)  In fact
column49: VanDyck had been suffering dizzy spells since 2002
column50: a condition for which she had  been taking medication.  (Tr.  19-20.)   8.   Although she never shared her medical information with Old Time Tap
column51: she had also   suffered a mild stroke in 2002.  (Tr.  19-20
column52: 41.)   9.   Don Jones had no knowledge ofVan Dyck' s medical conditions
column53: and he never noticed   any medical condition affecting Van Dyck's work in any way.  (Tr. 41
column55: Don Jones saw VanDyck taking some pills
column56: and he asked her about   them
column57: but only to ensure that she was not using illegal drugs.  (Tr.  115.)   11.   VanDyck was scheduled to work the evening of December 14
column58: 2003.  She had been  released from the hospital earlier that day and initially thought she was well enough to go to work.  But as the day went on she started feeling ill
column59: and so she called to say she couldn't come in because
column61: she had had a dizzy spell
column65: 64.)  Although she believes  she  spoke  directly  with  Don Jones
column66: he  denies  speaking  with  her;  he  believes  he  learned  of her  absence from the bartender who was on duty earlier that day.  (Tr.  23
column69: VanDyck did not work the night of December 14
column70: and someone else   covered her shift.  (Tr. 25
column71: 103-104.)   13.   VanDyck recalls phoning or visiting the Old Time Tap on several other occasions  after December 14.  She left messages for Don Jones but got no response.  (Tr. 25-26
column75: that her recollection of how many times she went to the Tap to speak with Don  Jones is  not good.  (Tr. 43-44.)  She believes that on December 16
column76: she spoke with  Don Jones and  he told her he did not  want her to  return because she  was  ""a risk and a liability.""  (Tr.  27.)  She  recalls calling him again and leaving messages
column77: but she never received a return call.  (Tr.  26-27.)  Don Jones denies this
column79: and further denies having had any phone conversations with Van  Dyck after her last day of work
column83: because he never heard from VanDyck after December 14
column84: he  thought she had  simply failed  to  show  up  on  Sunday
column87: and  he  asked  the  Tuesday night bartender
column89: to fill  in for her.  (Tr.  104-105.)   15.   The only telephone at the Old Time Tap is  a pay phone
column90: which both customers and  management use.  (Tr. 60.)  When VanDyck was on duty
column91: she answered the phone nine times out   2    of ten
column92: and it is  likely that other bartenders answered the phone when they were on duty.  (Tr. 60.)  There is  no answering machine on this phone.  (Tr.  117.)   16.   By chance
column93: VanDyck and Don Jones ran into each other at a local hardware store in  January 2004.  (Tr. 27
column96: ""What's up  with work?"" he told  her they had replaced her.  (Tr.  27
column98: who had more seniority than VanDyck
column99: took the Sunday evening   shift during the month ofJanuary.  (Tr.  119-120.)   18.   The  bartender  whom  Van  Dyck  had  replaced
column101: returned  from  her   maternity leave on Wednesday
column105: at the time of her injury
column106: she   was working only one night per week.  (Tr.  20
column107: 34.)   20.   VanDyck was out of work for approximately ten months until November  l
column109: when she took a job as a cashier in Hammond
column110: Indiana.  (Tr.  68.)   21.   She estimates her lost income for this ten-month period amounts to $2
column113: which she estimates would have totaled $2
column116: that she never kept track of tips and the amount may have been significantly lower.  (Tr. 71-72.)   22.   Because ofPolozet's return to work
column117: VanDyck's job as a fill-in bartender would have   ended February  l
column119: in any event.   23.   Although VanDyck offered medical records showing substantial medical bills related  to her December 10
column122: e.g. Complainant's Exhibits A and B
column123: there was no contention that  Old Time Tap was responsible for that injury.  Only the last page of Exhibit A was  received into  evidence.  (Tr. 92.)   B.   Credibility   24.   The hearing officer found Ms. VanDyck very credible and very precise.  In addition  to her own testimony
column126: to testify.  Mr. Bleege was also  found  very credible; however
column127: he had little if anything to say that was relevant to Ms.  VanDyck's  claim.   25.   Respondent's witnesses were Don and Christine Jones
column128: the owners of Old Time Tap.   They were also found credible.   26.   The hearing officer noted that during the course of the hearing
column129: each of the witnesses   for both sides appeared to make every effort to testify honestly.   3   III.   CONCLUSIONS OF LAW   This case arises under Section 2-160-030 of the Chicago Human Rights Ordinance
column130: which  provides:  ""No person shall directly or indirectly discriminate against any individual  in hiring ...  discharge  .  .  .  or  any  other  term  or  condition  of employment  because  of the  individual's  .  .  .  disability.""  It  is  Complainant's  burden to  prove
column131: by a  preponderance of the  evidence
column132: that  her  disability motivated the Respondent to discharge her.  See
column136: 2000).  A disability is defined under the Regulations implementing  the Human Rights Ordinance as ""a determinable physical or mental characteristic which may result  from  disease
column139: or functional  disorder.""  Part  100(11).  The  definition also includes ""the perception of such a characteristic.""  Id.  The Commission has held that  to be actionable
column140: the medical condition must not be insubstantial or transitory.  See
column145: 1997).  Complainant's initial burden is to prove  that:   She is  a member of the  protected class (a person with a disability or perceived as  such);   She was performing her job to her employer's legitimate expectations;   She suffered an adverse employment action; and   Similarly situated employees did not suffer the same adverse employment action.   Wehbe v.  Contacts & Specs
column148: 411  U.S. 792 (1973). 1  Respondent contests each of these elements.   Turning to the first element
column149: Complainant must establish by a preponderance of the evidence  that  she  was  a  person  with  a  disability  or  that  she  was  perceived  as  such.  The  only  detail  Complainant provided about her disability is that it was ""related to [her] head injury.""  Complaint
column150: '1[11.  This vague  and non-specific  allegation falls  short of the ""determinable physical  or mental  characteristic"" required by the Regulation.  At the hearing
column151: Complainant testified that she told her  employer she had gotten dizzy
column152: which adds some specificity.  But her dizziness was only a transitory  condition
column153: which the Commission has  held  insufficient to satisfy the Ordinance.  Jacobs
column155: the  evidence  was  overwhelming  that  Old  Time  Tap  was  never  aware  of  any  ""determinable"" medical condition that would meet the definition.  There is  no evidence that any  agent of Old Time Tap learned anything about VanDyck's December 10 injury other than that she  had  become  dizzy  and  hurt  her  head.  There  is  simply  no  evidence  to  suggest  that  Don  Jones  perceived VanDyck as someone with a determinable non-temporary medical characteristic of any   Under the McDonnell·Douglas method of proof
column156: if a complainant establishes a prima facie case of   discrimination
column157: the respondent then has the  burden of articulating a non·discriminatory basis for  its actions.  The  burden then shifts back to complainant to  prove that the basis offered by the respondent is pretextual.  See
column163: 1995).   4   •    sort.  Complainant has  not  proved  the  first  element of her prima facie  case
column164: and  therefore  her  complaint must be dismissed.   If we were to address the remaining elements of the prima facie case
column165: Complainant would  prevail  on  the  second  but  lose  on  the  third  and  fourth.  Although  Respondent  presented  some  testimony suggesting that VanDyck was not always  sufficiently attentive to the customers of Old  Time Tap
column166: the hearing officer found that she was performing her job to her employer's reasonable  expectations.  Thus
column167: she met her burden on the second element of proof of her prima facie case.   As  for the  third element
column168: it  is  highly disputed  whether Complainant suffered  an  adverse  employment action when she was replaced.  She testified that she attempted to advise her employer  that she was  ready to  return to  work on December 21
column169: but Don Jones recalled receiving no such  message.  As noted above
column170: both witnesses were very credible.  The hearing officer was unable to give  the testimony of one witness more weight than the other.  While the hearing officer had the distinct  impression  that  Van  Dyck  sincerely  believed  she  spoke  directly  with  Don  Jones  on or  before  December 21
column171: and that he told her she was a ""risk and a liability
column172: Don Jones was found equally  credible in denying any such conversation.  In fact
column173: he denied making any decision to replace Van  Dyck and explained that her position was filled first by another bartender with more seniority and  then by the  bartender who returned from  maternity leave.  Because the evidence on this  point is  evenly matched
column174: the  Complainant has  failed  to establish this  element by a preponderance of the  evidence
column175: as  required for her to prevail.   With regard to the fourth element
column177: Complainant  did not present evidence that any comparable employee at Old Time Tap was treated better than she  was in similar circumstances.  Again
column178: she failed to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that she  was treated differently from employees without a perceived or actual disability.   In  summary
column179: the  hearing  officer  concluded  that  Complainant  did  not  establish  by  a  preponderance of the evidence that she was fired because of a disability or perceived disability
column180: and  her  complaint  should  be  dismissed.  The  Commission  accepts  and  adopts  the  hearing  officer's  recommended findings  of fact  as  well  as  her conclusion that Complainant has failed to meet her  burden of proof that she was subjected to discrimination based on perceived disability.   IV   Conclusion   For these reasons
column181: the Commission adopts the hearing officer's recommendations and finds   for Respondent.   c:;:s::C M   JAW.\)   By:   Dana V.  Starks
column182: Chair and Commissioner   OMMISSION ON HUMAN RCLATIONS   5   "

column1: 11804`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2017construction/aug_2017/20170809_Vernon_80_Evanss_06w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                   Sewer Main Replacement Project #7139   August 9
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s “Building a New Chicago” infrastructure  improvement program
column5: I would like to provide you with  information about an upcoming sewer main construction project in your neighborhood.     In mid-August
column6: our private contractor will begin the work to install a new sewer in S.  Vernon Avenue (81st Street-80th Street)
column8: in S. Evans  Avenue (81st Street-80th Street)
column9: and in E. 80th Street (Evans-Champlain).  The old sewer  dates back to 1913 and needs to be replaced.     When we are working in the street
column10: we may close it to traffic for safety reasons
column11: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column12: a travel lane will  be left open for local traffic only.     We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am- 4pm).  We are agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column13: but cars will need to be moved  by the start of the next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking as possible.    We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do  everything possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column14: and  conducting ourselves as good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on  your street.     Should you have any questions or concerns
column15: you can either ask the construction foreman  during the project
column16: or call any of the following numbers:       24-Hour Service and Information Line:  311    6th Ward Office: 773-635-0006    DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635   Lastly
column17: if you don’t already have one
column18: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter  in your home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free  program
column19: go to www.metersave.org.     Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important  infrastructure improvement project.          Sincerely
column20: Randy Conner  Commissioner of Water Management

column2: Illinois 60604-3978  benefitshelp@cityofchicago.org  City of Chicago Richard M. Daley  Mayor  Steven J. Lux  City Comptroller  March 14
column3: 2008  BENEFITS BULLETIN  IT’S TIME FOR SPRING SCHOOL TERM   PROOF OF STUDENT STATUS  If your continuous service date shows you were hired on or after August  1
column5: and  if  you  are  not  a  sworn  police  officer  or  a  uniformed  firefighter
column6: medical  benefits  for your eligible dependent(s) will terminate at midnight prior to their 19th birthday.  Medical benefits can be extended until their 22nd birthday
column7: if you submit satisfactory “proof of student status” in both the Spring and Fall each year (within required time frame) confirming  that  your  eligible  dependent(s)  are  full-time students at an accredited college or university.  Important  Note: The  student’s  school  determines  the  definition of full-time.  Dental  benefits  will  terminate  for  your  eligible  dependent(s) at midnight prior to their 19th birthday whether they are full-time students or not.   Call  the  Health  Care  Services  Corporation (HCSC)  at  1-888-541-7107  to find  out  more  about continuation  of  dental  and/or  medical  coverage through the Public Health Service Act (PHSA) program.  If you are a sworn police officer or a uniformed firefighter
column8: or  if  your  continuous  service  date  shows  you  were  hired before August  1
column10: proof  of  student  status  is  not required for your eligible dependents.  For  complete  details  about  dependent  age  limits  for medical  and  dental  benefits
column11: please  visit  the  “general information”  section  of  the  Benefits  Management Division  website  www.cityofchicago.org/benefits and click on the words: Frequently Asked Questions.  Important Reminder: The deadline for the current Spring school term proof of  student status for continuation of medical benefits is Monday
column13: 2008. The following two documents must be submitted to the Benefits Management Division  twice a year or your eligible dependent(s) will not have medical benefits through the  City of Chicago for the full calendar year:  1) Original letter dated after 2/1/08 from the school’s Registrar’s Office confirming  full-time student status for the current school term.  2) Copy of full or partially paid tuition bill or grants for the current school term.  (SEE REVERSE SIDE)  3/08  UNDERSTANDING PROOF OF STUDENT STATUS GUIDELINES  • The letter from the school’s Registrar’s Office is often issued on the school’s  multicolored letterhead or has a raised seal. It cannot be a photocopy or a facsimile (fax). It cannot be dated prior to February. 1
column14: 2008 for the current Spring school term. It must state the student is enrolled on a “full-time” basis.  • The student’s name must appear on the copy of full or partially paid tuition bill or  grants for the current school term.  Various forms of proof of payment are acceptable including a copy of the student’s grant letter or student account printed from the Internet. The bill must be at least partially paid.  UNDERSTANDING FAMILY STATUS CHANGE GUIDELINES  If you wish to add or drop an eligible dependent from your coverage
column15: you must wait until the annual open enrollment period unless you experience a qualifying Family Status Change during the year:  Examples of family status changes  include the following:  Here are some examples of changes NOT considered family status changes:  • your marriage or divorce • your enrollment or termination of an eligible  domestic partner  • birth or adoption of a child • death of a spouse or covered dependent • a covered dependent reaching the   limiting age
column16: or   • a change in employment status for you   or your spouse  You must submit an enrollment form to the Benefits Management Division to add/delete within 30 days  of family status changes. You must also submit acceptable documentation to support the change in coverage within 60 days of your request.  1) You get married but you don’t notify the  Benefits Management Division for six months. Since you didn’t request coverage for the spouse within 30 days of your marriage
column17: you will have to wait until the next open enrollment period to add your new spouse.  2) You decide that you no longer want coverage  for your children. Since this is not a family status change
column18: you’ll have to wait until the next open enrollment period to drop coverage for your children.  IMPORTANT REMINDER IF YOU DIVORCE YOUR SPOUSE:  You Must Drop All Ineligible Dependents Including Divorced Spouses Or   You Will Be Billed The Cost Of Coverage And/Or Risk Financial Consequences.  3/08

column2: Accounting and General Office  Series: Information Technology            CLASS TITLE: MANAGER OF IS SECURITY AND OPERATIONS  CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS  Under direction of the Chief Security Officer
column3: manages the delivery of IT security services across the  City’s enterprise network including Network Security
column6: Architectural Advice and Incident Handling.      ESSENTIAL DUTIES   	  Works with the Chief Security Officer as a point person on citywide IT security initiatives as well    as the implementation
column7: revision and enforcement of security policies and procedures to ensure  information systems reliability and accessibility.       	  Develops network security architecture for the City
column9: Payment Card Industry (PCI) and Health Insurance Portability and Accountability  (HIPAA) compliance.  Identifies
column10: investigates and responds to information security incidents reported by client  departments and provides post-mortem analysis and recommendations.          Performs quarterly recertification of City’s firewall infrastructure configuration and rule base.      Analyzes existing network and firewall architecture against best practices and provides        recommendations to ensure alignment.     Oversees and conducts application and network security scans and works with technology     teams to develop remediation plans to ensure the protection of data.   	  Performs security audits
column12: performs risk and vulnerability assessments of     systems and implements processes and methods for addressing non-compliance to information  security standards.     Oversees quarterly and yearly security scans required for security best practices (e.g.
column13: HIPAA     and PCI).  Identifies foreseeable information security risks in order to comply with privacy and information  security policies and procedures.          Reviews and evaluates the impact of changes in software of infrastructure that may potentially     affect the confidentiality
column15: and availability of data.     Leads or participates in security meetings with peers and senior management.       Participates in the development
column18: testing and periodic review     and revision of the City’s disaster recovery plan.         Participates in the evaluation and selection of security applications and systems and provides     technical assistance on the impact that new solutions may have on the enterprise.     Assists in the preparation and management of the security operating budget.       Oversees vendors and other team members on security related projects.      Keeps abreast of security related technology
column19: best practices and regulations.       Prepares project
column20: status and ad hoc reports to keep management abreast of project progress

column1: 18019`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2017construction/jan_2017/20170111_Fifth_Tripp_Kedvale_24w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #1601069   January 11
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column5: I would like to provide you with information about an  upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.    By mid January 2017
column6: Department of Water Management (DWM) and Benchmark Construction  Company crews will begin the work to install 5
column7: 541 feet of new 8-inch water main in W. Fifth  Avenue
column8: from S. Kostner Avenue to W. Harrison Street
column10: from W. Harrison Street to  W. Arthington Street
column12: from W. Fifth Avenue to W. Arthington Street and   W. Harrison Street
column13: from S. Pulaski Road to S. Springfield Avenue. The old water main dates back to  1893
column14: and needs to be replaced.    If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column15: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column16: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.   By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column17: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column18: to the installation of new  pipes
column19: to the final restoration of the street.   When we are working in the street
column20: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column21: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column22: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.    We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column23: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.   We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column24: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.    Should you have any questions or concerns
column25: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column26: or call any of the following numbers:    •  24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311  •  24th Ward Office: 773-533-2400  •  DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635      Genwmnot03032016          Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main     When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column27: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column28: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column29: we may not be able to give you prior warning.   Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column30: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column32: including  any lead to maintain water quality.     Sediment
column34: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.  (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose spigot
column35: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where  the water comes into the home that is not used for  drinking water. Fully open the cold water tap and let  the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any  other cold water faucets on that floor for at least 5  minutes.   (2)Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.      If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column36: or if you would like your water  tested
column37: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water.   Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column38: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column39: taking a shower and  doing laundry.     MeterSave  Lastly
column40: if you don’t already have one
column41: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column42: go to  www.metersave.org.   Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.     Sincerely
